linkTarget.anchoringText: Mode I extension fractures are very common in outcrop maps. Ferrill et al. (2014) outlines the outcrop maps for the Eagle Ford Formation. Fig. 1 shows the west pavement of the mapped outcrop. Bed I, II and III show very well formed fracture networks, which contributes to well production if being hydraulically fractured. Fractures in Bed I is composed of two main fracture sets.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Pavement maps from competent Beds I, II, and III, respectively Ferrill et al (2014) m.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pavement maps from competent Beds I, II, and III, respectively Ferrill et al (2014) m.

linkTarget.bib:
Ferrill et al., 2014
D. A. Ferrill , R. N. McGinnis , A. P. Morris et al 2014. Control of Mechanical Stratigraphy on Bed-Restricted Jointing and Normal Faulting: Eagle Ford Formation, South-Central Texas . AAPG Bulletin
98 (11): 2477 2506 .

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 2 illustrates how to digitize the region highlighted by the red dotted cycle. According to the scale on the map, we first define both x and y scales, which is then followed by a line by line digitization. The final output consists of an N-by-4 matrix array, where N represents the number of fractures and each row corresponds to four coordinates of each fracture line segment. Fig. 3 plots the digitized fracture geometry.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: X and Y unit scale, and the red-dotted circle highlights the outcrop region that will be digitized, duplicated and simulated.

formatted-caption.caption-text: X and Y unit scale, and the red-dotted circle highlights the outcrop region that will be digitized, duplicated and simulated.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 2 illustrates how to digitize the region highlighted by the red dotted cycle. According to the scale on the map, we first define both x and y scales, which is then followed by a line by line digitization. The final output consists of an N-by-4 matrix array, where N represents the number of fractures and each row corresponds to four coordinates of each fracture line segment. Fig. 3 plots the digitized fracture geometry.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Top view of the digitized pattern of Eagle Ford outcrop maps.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Top view of the digitized pattern of Eagle Ford outcrop maps.

linkTarget.anchoringText: One possible method mimicking how natural fractures are distributed underground is to duplicate the digitized pattern up to the field scale both in the horizontal and vertical directions. Fig. 4 shows a picture of a larger outcrop map, which consists of three patterns along the horizontal direction, and four patterns along the vertical direction. The area of this outcrop map is around 0.5 acre. In total, there are 1584 natural fractures in Fig. 4.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Top view of the duplicated outcrop map, and the horizontal well trajectory indicated by the black line.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Top view of the duplicated outcrop map, and the horizontal well trajectory indicated by the black line.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 5 is reproduced from fig. 13 of Muralidharan et al. (2004) using the mean aperture value and standard deviations listed on the legend. With the increase in stresses from 500 psi up to 1500 psi, the lognormal peak shifts to the left. One interesting follow-up question is whether the nonuniform aperture distributions will affect fluid flow simulations in outcrop maps.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Various non-uniform aperture distributions under four different overburden pressures.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Various non-uniform aperture distributions under four different overburden pressures.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 6 shows the simulation mesh along a nonuniform fracture aperture. The purple ellipse highlights the region in which we observe a series of polygons to model aperture variations. The developed gridding approach has already been validated by field examples (Sun and Schechter 2015c) in primary depletion (Sun and Schechter 2015a) and CO2 EOR simulation cases (Sun, Zou, Sotelo, et al. 2016) .

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Modeling nonuniform fracture apetures along a fracture using unstructured grids.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Modeling nonuniform fracture apetures along a fracture using unstructured grids.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Cases 1 to 4 in Fig. 7 correspond to overburden stresses 0 psi, 500 psi, 1000 psi and 1500 psi, respectively. Fig. 8 plots histograms for four cases. Note that the generated nonuniform aperture values still follow the input lognormal distribution for each overburden stress. In the following section, we will simulate cases with nonuniform aperture distributions corresponding to cases 1 to 4.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Input fracture aperture variations for four overburen stresses in reservoir simulator.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Input fracture aperture variations for four overburen stresses in reservoir simulator.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Cases 1 to 4 in Fig. 7 correspond to overburden stresses 0 psi, 500 psi, 1000 psi and 1500 psi, respectively. Fig. 8 plots histograms for four cases. Note that the generated nonuniform aperture values still follow the input lognormal distribution for each overburden stress. In the following section, we will simulate cases with nonuniform aperture distributions corresponding to cases 1 to 4.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Histograms of nonuniform apertures for four overburden stresses.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Histograms of nonuniform apertures for four overburden stresses.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Where, kf is fracture permeability in mD; wf is nonuniform fracture width in ft; c is a scaling factor and assumed equal to 109. With the above equation, the fracture conductivity is proportional to the cubic of the fracture width. Fig. 9 plots fracture conductivity for the 20,000 pre-computed fracture gridblocks under four different overburden stresses.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Fracture conductivity plot for 20,000 pre-computed fracture gridblocks.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Fracture conductivity plot for 20,000 pre-computed fracture gridblocks.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 10 shows the top view of the simulation mesh for the outcrop map (Fig.4) with the nonuniform fracture aperture. Around the fractures, we observe small gridblocks. The closer to the reservoir boundary, the larger the gridblock size. In total, there are 186,493 cells for the single layer model. An enlarged view around the red dotted circle of Fig. 10 is shown in Fig. 11. Note that fracture geometries are modeled accurately. In addition, because of small fracture aperture, there is no significant difference in the simulation mesh between uniform and nonuniform fracture apertures.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Top view of the gridded outcrop pattern with 186,493 unstructured cells.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Top view of the gridded outcrop pattern with 186,493 unstructured cells.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 10 shows the top view of the simulation mesh for the outcrop map (Fig.4) with the nonuniform fracture aperture. Around the fractures, we observe small gridblocks. The closer to the reservoir boundary, the larger the gridblock size. In total, there are 186,493 cells for the single layer model. An enlarged view around the red dotted circle of Fig. 10 is shown in Fig. 11. Note that fracture geometries are modeled accurately. In addition, because of small fracture aperture, there is no significant difference in the simulation mesh between uniform and nonuniform fracture apertures.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Enlarged view around the red dotted circle of the reservoir in fig. 10.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Enlarged view around the red dotted circle of the reservoir in fig. 10.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figs. 11 to 14 show the pressure responses at 0.1 day, 1 day, 42 days, and 1827 days. Fractures play a dominant role in production performance. After 0.1 day’s production (Fig. 12), fractures around the horizontal wellbore are depleted. Because nonuniform fracture apertures are assigned to the fracture network, some fracture gridblocks show the behavior of finite fracture conductivity, and thus much lower pressure values.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Top view of the pressure graph after 0.1 days’ simulation.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Top view of the pressure graph after 0.1 days’ simulation.

linkTarget.anchoringText: After 1 day’s production (Fig. 13), six outcrop map patterns intersected by the horizontal well are depleted significantly, whereas other outcrop map patterns show less pressure decrease. This is because when we duplicated the digitized map to the whole reservoir scale, there might exist some fractures disconnected around the boundaries. One possible solution is to tweak the reservoir boundaries of each pattern a little bit, making sure these fractures cross the boundaries.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Top view of the pressure graph after 1 days’ simulation.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Top view of the pressure graph after 1 days’ simulation.

linkTarget.anchoringText: One possible solution is to tweak the reservoir boundaries of each pattern a little bit, making sure these fractures cross the boundaries. When the production period reaches 45 days (Fig. 14), the whole reservoir depletes to around 4500 psi. After around 600 days, the production rate becomes less than 1 STB/day for a long time up to 1827 days (Fig. 15).

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Top view of the pressure graph after 42 days’ simulation.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Top view of the pressure graph after 42 days’ simulation.

linkTarget.anchoringText: One possible solution is to tweak the reservoir boundaries of each pattern a little bit, making sure these fractures cross the boundaries. When the production period reaches 45 days (Fig. 14), the whole reservoir depletes to around 4500 psi. After around 600 days, the production rate becomes less than 1 STB/day for a long time up to 1827 days (Fig. 15).

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Top view of the pressure graph after 1827 days’ simulation.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Top view of the pressure graph after 1827 days’ simulation.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Similarly, we simulated the other three nonuniform fracture aperture distributions under overburden stresses 500, 1000, 1500 psi, respectively. Fig. 16 plots cumulative oil production vs. production time. Up to around 7 days (when the well constraint switches from the constant rate to the constant pressure), we observe a linear flow behavior that is cumulative oil increases linearly with production time.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Production performance of the outcrop map with less unstimualted area for nonuniform fracture aperture distributions under four different overburden stresses.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production performance of the outcrop map with less unstimualted area for nonuniform fracture aperture distributions under four different overburden stresses.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 17 (a) shows the corresponding plot of production rate vs. time. A common production behaviour from unconventional shale reservoirs is observed, which is a steep decline in the early period followed by a long tail. Fig. 17 (b) shows the zoom-in view around the early period. Note that early flow back of fracturing water was not taken into account in this study. The production rate starts from the highest value (100 STB/ day) and decreases with time.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Oil production rate under different overburden stresses (a); enlarged view of the production rate plot during the early period of production (b).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil production rate under different overburden stresses (a); enlarged view of the production rate plot during the early period of production (b).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Oil production rate under different overburden stresses
enlarged view of the production rate plot during the early period of production

linkTarget.anchoringText: In this section, the reservoir boundary is increased in order to have more unstimulated area. As seen in Fig. 18 – the gridded model with a large unstimulated reservoir area, there is no fracture in the reservoir region close to four boundaries. For the unstimulated area, we use large gridblocks in order to reduce computational cost.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Gridded reservoir model with large unstimulated reservoir areas.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Gridded reservoir model with large unstimulated reservoir areas.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 19 and Fig. 20 show pressure graphs at 1 day of production. Due to the existence of large unstimulated regions, matrix-fracture transient flow becomes more dominated after reservoir fluids in fractures are produced. Comparing Fig. 20 with Fig. 13, we observe very similar pressure graphs. Until 1 day, production rate remains 100 STB/days and fractures contribute to the production.

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: Top view of the pressure graph after 1 days’ simulation.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Top view of the pressure graph after 1 days’ simulation.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 19 and Fig. 20 show pressure graphs at 1 day of production. Due to the existence of large unstimulated regions, matrix-fracture transient flow becomes more dominated after reservoir fluids in fractures are produced. Comparing Fig. 20 with Fig. 13, we observe very similar pressure graphs. Until 1 day, production rate remains 100 STB/days and fractures contribute to the production.

image-wrap.label: Figure 20
image-wrap.caption: Enlarged view of the pressure graph in fig. 19 after 1 days’ simulation.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Enlarged view of the pressure graph in fig. 19 after 1 days’ simulation.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 21 shows cumulative oil production for all eight cases so far. The dotted curves represent the cases with large unstimulated areas. The solid curves are taken from the previous section. Four different overburden stresses are labeled by four different colors. With the increase of reservoir boundary, we do observe increase of cumulative oil production, even though there is no fracture in the unstimulated areas.

image-wrap.label: Figure 21
image-wrap.caption: Production performance of the outcrop map with large unstimualted areas for nonuniform fracture aperture distributions under four different overburden stresses.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production performance of the outcrop map with large unstimualted areas for nonuniform fracture aperture distributions under four different overburden stresses.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 22 plots corresponding oil production rates for eight cases. Fig. 22 (b) showed an enlarged view of Fig. 22 (a) during the early production period. Notice that all the dotted curves are above solid curves for each overburden stress because of the contributions of matrix-fracture transient flow. Fractures contribute to the early-time production, while the matrix contributes to the late-time production.

image-wrap.label: Figure 22
image-wrap.caption: Production rate under different overburden stresses.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production rate under different overburden stresses.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fracture permeabilities are recomputed based on the Cubic law. After remeshing, four new cases are simulated with the same reservoir, rock, and fluid properties. Cumulative oil and production rate are plotted on Fig. 23 and Fig. 24. With the increase of fracture mineralization, fracture aperture decreases, resulting in significant reduction in cumulative oil production. The recovery oil decreases from the original around 6 MSTB to 3 MSTB when nonuniform fracture apertures are decreased to 0.2 times of the original values.

image-wrap.label: Figure 23
image-wrap.caption: The impact of fracture mineralization of nonuniform fracture apertures on cumulative oil production.

formatted-caption.caption-text: The impact of fracture mineralization of nonuniform fracture apertures on cumulative oil production.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fracture permeabilities are recomputed based on the Cubic law. After remeshing, four new cases are simulated with the same reservoir, rock, and fluid properties. Cumulative oil and production rate are plotted on Fig. 23 and Fig. 24. With the increase of fracture mineralization, fracture aperture decreases, resulting in significant reduction in cumulative oil production. The recovery oil decreases from the original around 6 MSTB to 3 MSTB when nonuniform fracture apertures are decreased to 0.2 times of the original values.

image-wrap.label: Figure 24
image-wrap.caption: The impact of fracture mineralization of nonuniform fracture apertures on oil production rate.

formatted-caption.caption-text: The impact of fracture mineralization of nonuniform fracture apertures on oil production rate.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 25 compares the nonuniform fracture apertures with uniform fracture apertures that are derived from three different averaging approaches. The arithmetic method gives us the best cumulative oil production that is followed by the base case, geometric average, and harmonic average in Fig. 25. Even though we do observe a considerable difference between nonuniform and uniform fracture apertures, the cumulative oil curve of nonuniform fracture apertures is bounded by arithmetic and harmonic averaging approaches.

image-wrap.label: Figure 25
image-wrap.caption: Comparison of the nonuniform fracture aperture with uniform fracture apertures.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparison of the nonuniform fracture aperture with uniform fracture apertures.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 26 shows a plot of oil production rates for five hydraulically fractured horizontal wells in Eagle Ford formation. This plot is prepared from a public database (e.g., DrillingInfo). The well API numbers are listed on the legend. The red curve shows an averaged oil production profile. Note that there is a peak production rate around 100 days, which might be due to flowback of fracturing water.

image-wrap.label: Figure 26
image-wrap.caption: Eagle Ford Production Type Curves.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Eagle Ford Production Type Curves.
